I would love that this ad also talk about the custody of the kids after a divorce, the dads that cant see their kids and the system doesnt help. All that a guy has to pass in order to reconstruct his life when someone cheat on you and also keep the kids and doesnt allow you to see them. I’m aware that you’re free to do what you wish (I couldn’t care less regardless of what you decide to do) but it wouldn’t hurt to get a different angle of this subject. Good day.

@r_jay_russell You know, I genuinely am grateful for that response you have just given me, thank you.
I actually love to debate topics which I feel strongly about and also love to hear opposing views.
I agree about Instagram though, I’ve had a hell of a lot of personal attacks since this advert came out, some do just want to fight. Lol. It’s not often you can have a good debate without people acting out of line.

I agree with you on the overall message. I feel a lot of work needs to be done with both genders, I sometimes get overly upset as I’ve lost a few close Male friends to suicide so sometimes I get carried away trying to advocate for men’s rights and I forget to stop and remind myself that I am a woman and I don’t know what every man wants or how every man feels. I need to keep myself grounded a bit better in that respect. I’ve seen some men suffer due to women being given unfair advantages in certain areas and it makes me feel bad as I don’t always feel the allowances and shortcuts for women are justified, but that is another conversation entirely.

My overall view is that men should be whatever they want to be, whether that is masculine, feminine or a bit of both. And the same for women of course. As long as a person is a good person then they should embrace who they are and not feel ashamed for that.

Anyway I’ll end it there, I wish you a good evening.

@leanneyhunter that’s fair. And I didn’t mean to suggest that you were part of the problem or homophobic, etc. I appreciate the thoughtful response. Seems pretty rare on Instagram unfortunately! Critique of an ad is a good thing if it moves the conversation forward, in my opinion.  I noticed the men behind the grills too, but honestly didn’t think about it that way.  You’re right that it’s an over the top stereotype - I don’t think they meant to criticize men for grilling (at least I hope not- that would be pretty silly) but yeah it does come across that way.  As for the boys playing I’m not a parent so i can’t really weigh in on that - I don’t really know how kids relate to one anther these days, it’s probably different than it was when i was growing up in the 90s. Personally I appreciated the overall message of ad and Im glad that it’s getting people talking about these issues, and everyone’s experience/reaction to it is and should be different. but I realize it’s not like, a perfect piece of advertising.  Lots of advertising aimed at women is subtly critical of women’s bodies and appearances, and companies try to sell us stuff to “fix” what’s wrong with us.  Thsts changing now, sort of, but beauty and fashion are still billion dollar industries that profit on women wanting to change the way they look.  So I guess I find it kind of odd that a lot of people are upset about this one ad that is critical of men’s behavior. Anyway, you gave me some things to think about so thank you :)

@r_jay_russell it doesn’t have to be one or the other. I certainly do not fit that description and have many gay friend both Male and female.
I actually feel there is a good message underneath it all but strongly believe that it has been put across in a terrible way.
The main issue I have is when it said that some men behave well but many don’t (sorry I do not remember the exact wording) this gives the impression that the majority of men are at fault rather than the minority. It could have been worded far better.
I also feel the whole line up at barbecues was terrible stereotyping, it’s no better than a row of blonde women in bright pink clothing trying to decide which heels to buy. The father telling them off for rough housing was OTT, many girls and boys play like that and as long as they’re not actually fighting then it shouldn’t be made bad or attributed just to males. That’s the kind of thing which has angered me, not the message behind it. Or the guys watching women on tv as if it’s a bad thing, or as if women don’t enjoy looking at other women on tv.
Like I say it’s not at all what you’ve implied there but more the sexist and stereotypical way it was done.

@leanneyhunter that’s true. There are plenty of women who encourage this behavior in men— calling men “pussies” if they don’t work out 7x/week, telling men that they shouldn’t “act gay” when they express an interest in music/dance or prefer reading to sports, or that they should “man up” and “boys don’t cry” etc etc.  No ones trying to get rid of gender— just the rigid expectation that men have to be violent and aggressive to be seen as “real men.”
@k.r.tt nah the ad even implied approaching a woman to get to know her is toxic masculinity. Little boys are taught young to not hit girls, don't give me that bs.

I’m a man and I can’t understand why men don’t like that ad. I think its a wonderfull ad! Men complaining about this ad have a really fragile maskulinity or they identified themselves as the bullies in the video insted of those who are stepping up to stop the bullying.

I mean ya there are bad parts of masculinity that where developed in the past that we can do without, but I don’t want the next male generation to be made up of pussies. @leanneyhunter agreed absolutely but I do feel like we still need to address the problem of women being harassed. I grew up with men and boys in school constantly making remarks or attempting to touch me and they really thought that shit was okay. Hence why I do feel like we need something to tell those types of men that HEY THATS NOT OK AND IT NEEDS TO STOP. Quite frankly how I grew up I just can’t trust the men in the world because there’s always crazy people out there. Maybe our experiences are different but I also do feel like we need to address women praying on young boys and girls as well. But for right now we really do need movements like these.

@rebecca46and2 that again is just stereotyping people. Many religious people are kind and caring and would give you their very last. This reaction is exactly how I feel about the advert. You are saying what you’ve heard about some and applying it to the entire group. I feel that is discriminating.
@leanneyhunter well that's the thing. Religion drives a lot of people to do harm. That's why it's a bad thing.
@rebecca46and2 hating religion is fine, everybody can have their own view. However, hating those who follow the religion when they have done no harm, that is the bad thing.

@leanneyhunter nah, that wouldn't offend me. I agree that women shouldn't do those things, and I think it would be good if we mentioned it more so that we understand it's an issue. And I have no problem with anything that hates on any religion. It's a plague.

@rebecca46and2 or another way to look at it which I’ve mentioned elsewhere.
Imagine an anti terrorism advert which focused on one particular religion even though most of those people are good people. It would feed into the stereotype of that religion being a bad one and those people would receive even more undeserved hatred than what they already get.
@rebecca46and2 and even though we don’t do them, it would still offend because it gives the wrong impression of women.
@_deadserious_ it’s not just men who are against this type of stigmatisation though.

@nunu_duhhh yeah I don’t dispute that, I just spotted where you said ‘all’ women so I wanted to balance that.
We all know some men can be jerks, and some women can be too. I don’t feel this advert was fair though because they’d never make one aimed at women about false rape accusations or any female issues which apply to only the minority.
I genuinely feel there needs to be just as much of a voice defending our men as there is for us.
It’s always good to hear and consider both points of view.
@rebecca46and2 that’s a fair comment

@leanneyhunter I'll ask the same question of you that I asked to everyone else (and most people didn't bother answering). If you reverse it, in what ways would we be asking women to be better? What are the majority of us doing, or at least enough of us for it to be a big problem, that we ought to change? The few answers I did receive didn't offend me at all. Why? Because I agreed that women shouldn't be doing those things and they're things I don't do myself.

@rebecca46and2 
I genuinely disagree, I’m also saddened because I’m sick of men being made out to be these pigs who control society and women being made out to be held back and less powerful and stuff.

The most powerful people/leaders here in the UK are women - the Prime Minister, the Queen etc.
We’re not in a 3rd world country, and neither is the USA , we don’t need this harmful stigma against our men and boys.
They are literally the most disadvantaged group of people I know of in our society. They have a really bad deal in the developed world, and this just adds to that problem.
If an advert like this was made about women the feminists would go crazy.

@leanneyhunter you’re welcome! Somewhat agreed but I live in NY everyone is rushing and don’t notice what’s right in front of them. Also I’ve learned to defend myself and not depend on other people so I don’t feel safe around large groups of men also as I’ve mentioned my own experience previously 🙂.

@leanneyhunter unfortunately, the same cannot be said of frat parties. I personally don't feel afraid as I walk by construction sites. But I do feel pity for men who don't know a better way to interact with women than to hurl lewd comments as we walk by. So pathetic.

@nunu_duhhh not ALL girls, thank you. Your words don’t apply to me at least.
I feel safe walking past construction worker because I know if anything happened to me that most men are good and there would be a lot of them who would be there to help me.
@leanneyhunter 🙌
@jlanoue555 I’m with you on that one, as a female I have suffered more from modern day feminism than what I have from men. I fact I can’t think of a time I have ever suffered because of a man.

@rebecca46and2 I know the campaign to alot of people is nothing bad but given the general response the majority of people don't like the campaign anyways given the 20-1 dislike ratio and their stocks dropping

@jlanoue555 yeah I don't think anyone is looking to "wipe their record clean." I'm praising them for what I think is a very well done campaign, but that doesn't mean I'm going to start buying any of their products (I wax anyway). You needn't make things so black and white.

@leanneyhunter Men have held almost all the power in society for, oh, ever. It's true that we give a lot of help to women, because that is what good men do. It would be wrong to hold all the power and then also refuse to help those who don't hold it.

@rebecca46and2 I agree and I love to debate and hear other sides to an argument, but I genuinely believe a lot of that is due to women getting most of the help and being thought of as the ones who are disadvantaged. If men got the same treatment it could be different.

@rebecca46and2 they are led by a pedophile. They use child labor, hey use animals for testing, and they were caught overpricing female products. I'm sorry but they should not be praised for this ad and have their record wiped clean

@jlanoue555 that's a false premise. Saying that we can't expect anything to get better until we ourselves are perfect is an excellent way to ensure that nothing gets better, because no one will ever be perfect. All we can ever ask for is progress and the attempt to be better.
@jlanoue555 love Dollar Shave Club! They're a good company.

@nunu_duhhh I'm tired of being told I'm a rapist, bully, etc for my gender. Alot of women have gone out and boycotted gillete just as some men have been pro the advert. It's all opinionated. Gillete is in no the best them they can be! And until they do that they have no right to attack masculinity or men
@rebecca46and2 I havent bought from gillete in years. I use Dollar shave club

@jlanoue555 I can’t make you understand our side. Unfortunately I feel like that is something only women really will know. Idk if you’re angry at us?? But I will say that I’m just glad a company had the balls to say something in our defense. Unfortunately it got a lot of negativity which I couldn’t wrap my head around why but I guess I See now that it is men young and old just so tired of hearing about the shit most of them actually do and don’t want to hear anything about feminist bullshit that stands for what women have faced everyday of their damn lives for men to say their tired of hearing all of this ..... we’re tired of living it.
@julian_adolph
@jlanoue555 wait, so did you stop buying products from Proctor & Gamble and/or Gillette long ago like myself? I would personally be so happy if people started supporting more ethically run companies.

@jlanoue555 also your statistics are off because dare I remind you of all the women that have not come out yet about their rape? I have SO MANY friends in my life who were raped as kids and haven’t come out to authorities because of understandable reasons and for hopes their family doesn’t look at them as “disgusting”. A lot of people I know who are closed off and depressed I have found out to have been molested repeatedly during childhood and they still are too scared to go to the police because unfortunately that person is the person taking care of them and paying for a roof over their heads or so forth. Like yes weirdo women rape innocent people but even tho statistics also show that it is statutory rape yes it is still wrong but same for men who are 30 dating 18 years olds. Literally a report showed that the most thing searched on porn sites is teen and stepdad. What’s with this fetish of millions of men watching step dads have sex with their teenage daughters??

@nunu_duhhh and the majority of arguments arent "women rape too" the arguments are women can be toxic just as men can be and stop trying to make masculinity in anyway evil and stop pretending that these things have anything to do with masculinity

@nunu_duhhh I understand your point of view I do. But as a dude I'm tired of the media telling me that as a man my masculinity is in any way tied to toxicity. I'm tired of these things being labeled as something that is inherently tied to men. I've been accused of rape falsely. I've been at a party and told  girl she had a nice hat and been berated as a creep. I've been abused by women. If the ad was be the best human being you can be rather than say these things are tied to men and if it werent so one sided and biased I'd have nothing against it. You also need to realize it offends me that a company that openly tests on animals, that uses child labor over seas, that purposely over prices female products, and is run by someone who gas over 5 lawsuits of pedophilia agaisnt him. Is somehow gonna tell me what is morally okay

@jlanoue555 I’ve read all sides and I see what you’re saying I do. Although, I just want to use our current president as an example.. “grab her by the pussy”. How do you think we feel when we here our president saying this? It’s degrading and quite frankly scares the shit out of us. No statistics can tell you the actual fear ALL girls feel walking home by themselves even in daylight. Walking past construction sites hoping not to be distgustingly BADGERED by these men. I’ve had a crossing guard literally not do his job but was staring at me and said “nice ass. Where you headed?” So from personal experience I love this commercial dude. Set aside “WELL WOMEN RAPE TOO” and look at what this commercial is trying to really say. Like that moment when the guy is about to cat call a girl and his friend stops him like that is what they are targeting!! Dickheads!!!! And they are trying to show the next gen that these things are wrong and to not repeat the cycle of degrading women. I do see what you’re saying but I’m trying to show you what this commercial doesn’t say but is defending. I could say so many more examples but it just seems that everyone who is against this commercial doesn’t really understand it or refuses to understand.

The ad isn’t saying “some men act the right way.” It’s addressing the issues of sexual assault and the excuse that has been drilled in boys’ minds since they were a child: boys will be boys. The ad is stating (utilizing their own previous commercials) that this toxic way of thinking needs to stop now and it starts with us. That being a man isn’t fighting or being overly proud, it’s standing up for others. It’s ending a fight. It’s respecting the people around them. All men definitely are not bad, most are the kind of people that Gillette argues are the best a man can be. But the film shows that there are STILL toxic people in the community and THEY need to be held accountable. The men showed in the commercial aren’t meant to be a representation of the gender as a whole, but rather a piece that has to be addressed. I do not mean to attack you, I just implore you to see this commercial from a different perspective.
